article.title: Culture_of_Canada
article.paragraph: Use Canadian EnglishJuly 2015Use mdy datesMarch 2012Culture of Canada sidebarCanadian cultureis a term that embodies theCanadian artartistic,Canadian cuisineculinary,Canadian literatureliterary,Canadian humourhumour,Music of Canadamusical,Politics of Canadapoliticaland social elements that are representative of Canada and Canadians. Throughout Canada's history, its culture has been influenced byCulture of EuropeEuropean cultureand traditions, especiallyCulture of the United KingdomBritishandCulture of FranceFrench, and by its ownAboriginal peoples in Canadaindigenous cultures.cite bookSana LoueMartha SajatovicEncyclopedia of Immigrant Healthhttp://books.google.com/books?id2011Springer978-1-4419-5655-2337Over time, elements of the cultures of Canada's immigrant populations have become incorporated into mainstream Canadian culture.cite bookPaul R. MagocsiMulticultural History Society of OntarioEncyclopedia of Canada's Peopleshttp://books.google.com/books?id1999University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-2938-61186–1187The population has also been influenced byCulture of the United StatesAmerican culturebecause of a shared language, proximity and migration between the two countries.cite bookOrganisation for Economic Co-operation and DevelopmentEconomic and cultural transition towards a learning city: the case of Jenahttp://books.google.com/books?id1999OECD Publishing978-92-64-17015-548cite bookChristopher RicksLeonard MichaelsThe State of the languagehttp://books.google.com/books?id1990University of California Press978-0-520-05906-119

Canada is often characterized as being "veryprogressivismprogressive,Cultural diversitydiverse, andMulticulturalism in Canadamulticultural".cite bookAnne-Marie Mooney CotterCulture clash: an international legal perspective on ethnic discriminationhttp://books.google.com/books?id2011Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.978-1-4094-1936-5176Canada's culture draws from its broad range of constituent nationalities, and policies that promote ajust societyare constitutionally protected.cite bookSheila PettyGarry SherbertAnnie GérinCanadian Cultural Poesis: Essays on Canadian Culturehttp://books.google.com/books?id2006Wilfrid Laurier Univ. Press978-0-88920-486-7348Canadian Government policiessuch asHealth care in Canadapublicly funded health care; higher and moreIncome taxes in Canadaprogressive taxation; outlawingCapital punishment in Canadacapital punishment; strong efforts to eliminatepoverty in Canadapoverty; an emphasis onCultural mosaiccultural diversity; strictGun politics in Canadagun control; and most recently, legalizingSame-sex marriage in Canadasame-sex marriageare social indicators of Canada's political and cultural values.cite bookDarrell BrickerJohn WrightIpsos-Reid (Firm)What Canadians think- about almost- everythinghttp://books.google.com/books?id2005Doubleday Canada978-0-385-65985-78–20

Canada'sGovernment of Canadafederal governmenthas influenced Canadian culture with programs, laws and institutions. It has created crown corporations to promote Canadian culture through media, such as theCanadian Broadcasting Corporation(CBC) and theNational Film Board of Canada(NFB), and promotes many events which it considers to promote Canadian traditions. It has also tried toCanadian cultural protectionismprotect Canadian cultureby setting legal minimums onCanadian contentin many media using bodies like theCanadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission(CRTC).cite webNational Film Board of CanadaNational Film Board of Canadahttp://www.nfb.ca/atonf/organisation.php?vMandate of the National Film Board2005March 15, 2006http://web.archive.org/web/20060421170854/http://www.nfb.ca/atonf/organisation.php?vApril 21, 2006
article.heading: Development of Canadian culture
Historical influences
article.paragraph: MainCanadiansHistory of CanadaFile:Fur traders in canada 1777.jpgrightthumbFur tradersat work as depicted in 1777 byClaude J. SauthierFor tens of thousands of years, Canada was inhabited byAboriginal peoples in CanadaAboriginal peoplesfrom a variety ofClassification of indigenous peoples of the Americasdifferent culturesand ofIndigenous languages of the Americasseveral major linguistic groupings.cite bookTrevor W. Harrison, John W. FriesenTrevor HarrisonJohn W. FriesenCanadian Society in the Twenty-first Century: An Historical Sociological Approachhttp://books.google.com/books?id2010Canadian Scholars’ Press978-1-55130-371-0186Although not without conflict and bloodshed, early European interactions withFirst NationsandInuitpopulations in what is now Canada were arguably peaceful.cite bookDavid L. PrestonThe Texture of Contact: European and Indian Settler Communities on the Frontiers of Iroquoia, 1667–1783http://books.google.com/books?id2009U of Nebraska Press978-0-8032-2549-743–44First Nations andMtis people (Canada)Mtispeoples played a critical part in the development ofFormer colonies and territories in CanadaEuropean colonies in Canada, particularly for their role in assisting Europeancoureur des boisandvoyageursin the exploration of the continent during theNorth American fur trade.cite bookJ.R. MillerCompact, Contract, Covenant: Aboriginal Treaty-Making in Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2009University of Toronto Press978-1-4426-9227-534Combined with lateEconomic history of Canadaeconomic developmentin many regions, this comparably nonbelligerent early history allowed Aboriginal Canadians to have a lasting influence on the national culture (see:The Canadian Crown and Aboriginal peoples).cite bookPatrick MacklemIndigenous difference and the Constitution of Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2001University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-8049-3136Over the course of three centuries, countless North American Indigenous words, inventions, concepts, and games have become an everyday part ofSpoken languages of CanadaCanadian languageand use.cite webNewhouseDavidhttp://www.cst.ed.ac.uk/2005conference/papers/Newhouse_paper.pdfPDFHidden in Plain Sight Aboriginal Contributions to Canada and Canadian Identity Creating a new Indian ProblemCentre of Canadian Studies, University of EdinburghOctober 17, 2009List of place names in Canada of aboriginal originMany places in Canada, both natural features and human habitations, use indigenous names. TheName of Canadaname "Canada"itself derives from theLaurentian languageSt. Lawrence Iroquoianword meaning "village" or "settlement".The name of Canada's capital cityOttawacomes from theAlgonquin languageterm "adawe" meaning "to trade".cite webhttp://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ai/mr/is/info106-eng.aspAboriginal place names contribute to a rich tapestryIndian and Northern Affairs CanadaOctober 17, 2009

link.target: File:Keep All Canadians Busy - Victory bonds poster.jpg
link.part: A Canadianwar bondposter that depicts an industrious beaver aNational symbols of Canadanational symbol of Canada

article.paragraph: TheFrench CanadianFrenchoriginally settledNew Francealong the shores of the Atlantic Ocean andSaint Lawrence Riverduring the early part of the 17th century.cite bookJohn C. HudsonAcross this land: a regional geography of the United States and Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2002JHU Press978-0-8018-6567-115Themes and symbols of pioneers, trappers, and traders played an important part in the early development of French Canadian culture.cite webhttp://www.canadiana.org/citm/themes/pioneers/pioneers7_e.html Canada in the Making: Pioneers and Immigrants The History Channel August 25, 2005 November 30, 2006 TheKingdom of Great BritainBritishconquest of New France during the mid-18th century brought 70,000wikt:FrancophoneFrancophonesunder British rule, creating a need for compromise and accommodation.cite bookJohn PowellEncyclopedia of North American Immigrationhttp://books.google.com/books?id2009Infobase Publishing978-1-4381-1012-745The migration of 40,000 to 50,000United Empire Loyalistsfrom theThirteen Coloniesduring theAmerican Revolution(17751783) brought American colonial influences.Following theWar of 1812a large wave ofIrish CanadianIrish,Scottish CanadianScottishandEnglish CanadianEnglishsettlers arrived inUpper CanadaandLower Canada.

TheCanadian Forcesand overall civilian participation in theMilitary history of Canada during World War IFirst World WarandMilitary history of Canada during World War IISecond World Warhelped to fosterCanadian nationalism,cite bookEdited by R. Douglas FrancisCanada and the British World: Culture, Migration, and Identityhttp://books.google.com/books?idUBC Press978-0-7748-4031-622011-11-01however in 1917 and 1944Conscription Crisis of 1917conscription crisis'shighlighted the considerable rift along ethnic lines between Anglophones and Francophones.cite bookChristopher Edward TaucarCanadian Federalism and Quebec Sovereigntyhttp://books.google.com/books?id472002American university studies: Political science978-0-8204-6242-447–48As a result of the First and Second World Wars, the Government of Canada became more assertive and less deferential to British authority.cite bookWayne C. ThompsonCanada World Todayhttp://books.google.com/books?id2013Rowman & Littlefield978-1-4758-0474-461Canada until the 1940s saw itself in terms ofEnglish CanadianEnglishandFrench CanadianFrenchcultural, linguistic and political identities, and to some extent aboriginal.cite bookGuy M. RobinsonA Social geography of Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id1991Dundurn Press Ltd.978-1-55002-092-286

Legislative restrictions on immigration (such as theContinuous journey regulationandChinese Immigration Act, 1923Chinese Immigration Act) that had favoured British, American and other European immigrants (such asCanadians of Dutch descentDutch,German CanadianGerman,Italian CanadiansItalian,Polish CanadiansPolish,Swedish CanadianSwedishandUkrainian CanadianUkrainian) were amended during the 1960s,cite bookPeter KivistoMulticulturalism in a Global Societyhttp://books.google.com/books?id2008John Wiley & Sons978-0-470-69480-090cite bookPatricia E.. BromleyHuman Rights, Diversity, and National Identity: Changes in Civic Education Textbooks Cross-nationally (1970–2008) and in British Columbia (1871–2008)http://books.google.com/books?id2011Stanford University107–108STANFORD:XT006FZ3167resulting in an influx of diverse people from Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean.cite bookEdward KsenychDavid LiuConflict, order and action: readings in sociologyhttp://books.google.com/books?id2001Canadian Scholars' Press978-1-55130-192-1407By the end of the 20th century, immigrants were increasinglyChinese CanadianChinese,Indian CanadianIndian,Vietnamese CanadianVietnamese,Jamaican CanadianJamaican,Filipino CanadianFilipino,Lebanese CanadiansLebaneseandHaitian CanadianHaitian.cite webImmigration Policy in the 1970shttp://www.multiculturalcanada.ca/Encyclopedia/A-Z/i2/10Canadian Heritage (Multicultural Canada)2004April 12, 2010As of 2006, Canada has grown to haveEthnic origins of people in Canadathirty four ethnic groupswith at least one hundred thousand members each, of which eleven have over 1,000,000 people and numerous others are represented in smaller numbers.cite webhttp://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/2006/rt-td/index-eng.cfm2006 Census release topicsStatistics CanadaJanuary 16, 201116.2% of the population self identify as avisible minority.

link.part: TheDr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese GardeninChinatown, VancouverVancouver's Chinatownis the first full-size Chinese or "scholars"Chinese gardengardenbuilt outside of China

article.paragraph: Canada has also evolved to beReligion in CanadareligiouslyandLanguages of Canadalinguisticallydiverse, encompassing a wide range of dialects, beliefs and customs.cite bookDianne R. HalesLara LauzonAn Invitation to Healthhttp://books.google.com/books?idApril 2009Cengage Learning978-0-17-650009-2440cite bookWilliam DownesLanguage and societyhttp://books.google.com/books?id1998Cambridge University Press978-0-521-45663-047TheCanada 2011 Census2011 Canadian censusreported a population count of 33,121,175 individuals of whom 67.3% identify as beingChristians; of these,CatholicismCatholicsmake up the largest group, accounting for 38.7 percent of the population.The largest Protestant denomination is theUnited Church of Canada(accounting for 6.1% of Canadians), followed byAnglican Church of CanadaAnglicans(5.0%), andBaptists(1.9%).About 23.9% of Canadians declareIrreligionno religiousaffiliation, includingAgnosticismagnostics,Atheismatheists,Humanismhumanists, and other groups.The remaining are affiliated with non-Christian religions, the largest of which isIslam(3.2%), followed byHinduism(1.5%),Sikhism(1.4%)Buddhism(1.1%) andJudaism(1.0%).cite webhttp://www.statcan.gc.ca/daily-quotidien/130508/dq130508b-eng.htm?HPAReligions in Canada—Census 2011Statistics Canada/Statistique CanadaEnglish and French are thefirst languagesof approximately 60% and 20% of the population; however in 2011, nearly 6.8 million Canadians listed a non-official language as their mother tongue.cite webhttp://canadaonline.about.com/od/statistics/a/languages-canada-2011-census.htmWhat Languages Do Canadians Speak? Language Statistics From the 2011 Census of CanadaAbout.com: Canada OnlineOctober 31, 2012November 26, 2012Some of the most common non-official first languages include Chinese (mainlyYue ChineseCantonesewith 1,072,555 first-language speakers);Punjabi languagePunjabi(430,705); Spanish (410,670); German (409,200); and Italian (407,490).cite webStatistics Canadahttp://www.statcan.gc.ca/tables-tableaux/sum-som/l01/cst01/demo11a-eng.htmPopulation by mother tongue, by province and territoryJanuary 2013July 4, 2013
article.heading: Evolution of legislation
article.paragraph: French Canada's early development was relatively cohesive during the 17th and 18th centuries, and this was preserved by theQuebec Actof 1774, which allowed Roman Catholics to hold offices and practice their faith.cite encyclopediahttp://www.answers.com/topic/quebec-city-quebec Quebec Columbia University Press The Columbia Electronic Encyclopedia, Sixth Edition 2003 November 30, 2006 In 1867, theConstitution Act, 1867Constitution Actwas thought to meet the growing calls for Canadian autonomy while avoiding the overly strong decentralization that contributed to theAmerican Civil WarCivil Warin the United States.cite encyclopediahttp://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNmAmerican Civil war Historica Founcation The Canadian Encyclopedia 2003 November 30, 2006 The compromises reached during this time between the English- and French-speakingFathers of Confederationset Canada on a path toMultilingualismbilingualismwhich in turn contributed to an acceptance of diversity.cite bookFrançois Vaillancourt, Olivier CocheOfficial Language Policies at the Federal Level in Canada:costs and Benefits in 2006http://books.google.com/books?idThe Fraser Institute11GGKEY:B3Y7U7SKGUDThe English and French languages have had limited constitutional protection since 1867 and full official status since 1969.Section 133 of the Constitution Act of 1867 (BNA Act) guarantees that both languages may be used in theParliament of Canada.cite bookPaul André LinteauRené DurocherJean-Claude RobertQuebec, a history, 1867–1929http://books.google.com/books?id1983James Lorimer & Company978-0-88862-604-2219Canada adopted itsOfficial Languages Act (Canada)first Official Languages Actin 1969, giving English and French equal status in the government of Canada.Doing so makes them "official" languages, having preferred status in law over all otherLanguages of Canadalanguages used in Canada.cite bookJochen KoselThe Language Situation in Canada with Special Regard to Quebechttp://books.google.com/books?id2010GRIN Verlag978-3-640-65926-515

link.part: Monument toMulticulturalism in CanadaMulticulturalism, by Francesco Pirelli in Toronto.

article.paragraph: Prior to the advent of theCanadian Bill of Rightsin 1960 and its successor theCanadian Charter of Rights and Freedomsin 1982, the laws of Canada did not provide much in the way ofHuman rights in Canadacivil rightsand this issue was typically of limited concern to the courts.cite bookJoan ChurchChristian SchulzeHennie StrydomHuman rights from a comparative and international law perspectivehttp://books.google.com/books?id2007Unisa Press978-1-86888-361-582Canada since the 1960s has placed emphasis on equality and inclusiveness for all people.cite bookChristopher MacLennanToward the Charter: Canadians and the Demand for a National Bill of Rights, 1929–1960http://books.google.com/books?id2004McGill-Queen's University Press978-0-7735-2536-8119For example, in 1995, theSupreme Court of Canadaruled inEgan v. Canadathatsexual orientationshould be "read in" toSection Fifteen of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, a part of theConstitution of CanadaguaranteeingHuman rights in Canadaequal rightsto all Canadians.cite bookLinda Silver DranoffEvery Canadian's Guide to the Law: Fourth Editionhttp://books.google.com/books?idFebruary 3, 20122011HarperCollins Canada978-1-4434-0559-1373–Following a series of decisions by provincial courts and the Supreme Court of Canada, on July 20, 2005, theCivil Marriage Act(Bill C-38) receivedRoyal Assent, legalizingsame-sex marriage in Canada.cite bookPaul Ubaldo AngeliniOur Society: Human Diversity in Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2011Cengage Learning978-0-17-650354-3315Canada thus became the fourth country to officially sanction same-sex marriage worldwide, afterSame-sex marriage in the NetherlandsThe Netherlands,Same-sex marriage in BelgiumBelgium, andSame-sex marriage in SpainSpain.cite bookAnne-Marie Mooney CotterAsk no questions: an international legal analysis on sexual orientation discriminationhttp://books.google.com/books?id2010Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.978-0-7546-7791-8140Furthermore, sexual orientation was included as a protected status in the human-rights laws of the federal government and of all provinces and territories.cite bookShirley R. SteinbergDiversity and Multiculturalismhttp://books.google.com/books?id2009Peter Lang978-1-4331-0345-2184

Today, Canada has a diverse makeup of ethnicities and nationalities and constitutional protection for policies that promote multiculturalism rather thancultural assimilationor a single national myth.cite bookDavid DeRoccoJohn F. ChabotFrom Sea to Sea to Sea: A Newcomer's Guide to Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2008Full Blast Productions978-0-9784738-4-613In Quebec, cultural identity is strong, and many French-speaking commentators speak of aCulture of QuebecQuebec cultureas distinguished from English Canadian culture.cite bookDaniel FranklinMichael J. BaunPolitical culture and constitutionalism: a comparative approachhttp://books.google.com/books?id1995M.E. Sharpe978-1-56324-416-261However, as a whole, Canada is in theory, acultural mosaica collection of several regional, aboriginal, and ethnic subcultures.cite bookAllan D. EnglishUnderstanding Military Culture: A Canadian Perspectivehttp://books.google.com/books?id2004McGill-Queen's University Press978-0-7735-7171-6111cite bookBurgess, Ann CarrollBurgess, TomGuide to Western Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2005Globe Pequot Press978-0-7627-2987-631CeltsCelticinfluences have allowed survival of non-English dialects inNova ScotiaandNewfoundland and LabradorNewfoundland;cite bookJohn Thomas KochCeltic culture: a historical encyclopediahttp://books.google.com/books?id2006ABC-CLIO978-1-85109-440-0376Canada's Pacific trade has also brought a large Chinese influence intoBritish Columbiaand other areas.cite bookFen Osler HampsonCanada Among Nations, 1997: Asia Pacific Face-Offhttp://books.google.com/books?id1997McGill-Queen's University Press978-0-88629-327-7234Multiculturalism in Canadawas adopted as the official policy of the Canadian government during the prime ministership ofPierre Trudeau, and is enshrined inSection Twenty-seven of the Canadian Charter of Rights and FreedomsSection 27 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.cite bookJonathan L. Black-BranchCanadian Education AssociationMaking Sense of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedomshttp://books.google.com/books?id1995Canadian Education Association978-0-920315-78-138cite bookJames S. DuncanDavid LeyPlace/culture/representationhttp://books.google.com/books?id1993Routledge978-0-415-09451-1205–In parts of Canada, especially the major cities ofMontreal,Vancouver,OttawaandToronto, multiculturalism itself is the cultural norm in many urban communities.cite journalhttp://ceris.metropolis.net/Virtual%20Library/other/wallace1/chapt5.html Planning Amidst Diversity: The Challenges of Multiculturalism in Urban and Suburban Greater Toronto University of Waterloo Marcia Wallace 1999 November 30, 2006
article.heading: Identity

link.part: Themaple leafis the symbol most associated withCanadian identity.

article.paragraph: Canada's large geographic size, the presence of a significant number of indigenous peoples, the conquest of one European linguistic population by another and relatively openimmigration policyhave led to an extremelyethnic groups in Canadadiverse society. As a result, the issue of Canadian identity remains under scrutiny.MacGregor, p.39Journalist and professorAndrew Cohen (journalist)Andrew Cohenwrote in 2007:QuoteThe Canadian Identity, as it has come to be known, is as elusive as the [[Bigfoot|Sasquatch]] and [[Ogopogo]]. It has animated—and frustrated—generations of statesmen, historians, writers, artists, philosophers, and the National Film Board...Canada resists easy definition.Andrew Cohen<arg name="The Unfinished Canadian: The People We Are<ref name">"Cohen2008zxc">{{cite book|author

The question of Canadian identity was traditionally dominated by three fundamental themes: first, the often conflicted relations between English Canadians and French Canadians stemming from the French Canadian imperative for cultural and linguistic survival; secondly, the generally close ties between English Canadians and theBritish Empire, resulting in a gradual political process towards complete independence from the imperial power; and finally, the close proximity of English-speaking Canadians to the United States.cite bookMartin N. MargerRace and Ethnic Relations: American and Global Perspectiveshttp://books.google.com/books?id2011Cengage Learning978-1-111-18638-8433In the 20th century, immigrants from African,Caribbeanand Asian nationalities have shaped the Canadian identity, a process that continues today with the ongoing arrival of large numbers of immigrants from non-British or non-French backgrounds, adding the theme of multiculturalism to the debate.cite bookPhilip ResnickThe European Roots Of Canadian Identityhttp://books.google.com/books?id2005University of Toronto Press978-1-55111-705-863cite bookRoy MacGregorCanadianshttp://books.google.com/books?id2008Penguin Group (Canada)978-0-14-318162-0Much of the debate over contemporary Canadian identity is argued in political terms, and defines Canada as a country defined by its government policies, which are thought to reflect deeper cultural values.cite bookSteven Alexander KennettSecuring the Social Union: A Commentary on the Decentralized Approachhttp://books.google.com/books?id1998IIGR, Queen's University978-0-88911-767-96
article.heading: Nationalism and protectionism
article.paragraph: MainCanadian nationalismQuebec nationalismCanadian cultural protectionismFile:St-Jean!042.jpgrightthumbQuebec's National Holiday(lang-frnoLa Fête nationale du Québec) is celebrated annually on June 24,Nativity of St. John the BaptistSt. John the Baptist DayIn general, Canadian nationalists are highly concerned about the protection of Canadian sovereignty and loyalty to theMonarchy of CanadaCanadian State, placing them in theLiberal nationalismcivic nationalistcategory. It has likewise often been suggested that anti-Americanism plays a prominent role in Canadian nationalist ideologies.cite bookBrendon O'ConnorAnti-Americanism: Comparative perspectiveshttp://books.google.com/books?id2007Greenwood Publishing Group978-1-84645-026-659A unified, bi-cultural, tolerant and sovereign Canada remains an ideological inspiration to many Canadian nationalists.cite bookPeter H. RussellConstitutional odyssey: can Canadians become a sovereign people?http://books.google.com/books?id2004University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-3777-0156AlternativelyFrench Canadiannationalism and support for maintaining French Canadian culture would inspireQuebec nationalismQuebec nationalists, many of whom were supporters of theQuebec sovereignty movementduring the late-20th century.cite bookDominique CliftQuebec nationalism in crisishttp://books.google.com/books?id1982McGill-Queen's University Press978-0-7735-0383-0106–108

Cultural protectionism in Canada has, since the mid-20th century, taken the form of conscious, interventionist attempts on the part of various Canadian governments to promote Canadian cultural production.cite bookJohn Carlos RoweA Concise Companion to American Studieshttp://books.google.com/books?id2010John Wiley and Sons978-1-4051-0924-6393Sharing aCanada United States borderlarge borderand (for the majority) a common language with the United States, Canada faces a difficult position in regard to American culture, be it direct attempts at the Canadian market or the general diffusion of American culture in the globalized media arena. While Canada tries to maintain its cultural differences, it also must balance this with responsibility in trade arrangements such as theGeneral Agreement on Tariffs and Trade(GATT) and theNorth American Free Trade Agreement(NAFTA).cite bookMarc RaboyMissed opportunities: the story of Canada's broadcasting policyhttp://books.google.com/books?id1990McGill-Queen's University Press978-0-7735-0775-3301
article.heading: Symbols
article.paragraph: MainNational symbols of CanadaCanadian royal symbolsFile:Stamp Canada 1859 5c.jpg200pxthumbOne of the national symbols of Canada, the beaver is depicted on theNickel (Canadian coin)Canadian five-cent pieceand was on the firstPostage stamps and postal history of CanadaCanadian postage stamp, c. 1859.Official symbols of Canada include themaple leaf,beaver, and theCanadian Horse.cite webhttp://www.canlii.org/ca/sta/n-10.7/National Horse of Canada ActCanlii.orgFebruary 25, 2011cite webhttp://www.pch.gc.ca/pgm/ceem-cced/symbl/o1-eng.cfmThe beaverPch.gc.caDecember 17, 2008February 25, 2011cite webhttp://www.pch.gc.ca/pgm/ceem-cced/symbl/o3-eng.cfmThe Maple LeafPch.gc.caNovember 17, 2008February 25, 2011Many official symbols of the country such as theFlag of Canadahave been changed or modified over the past few decades to 'Canadianize' them and de-emphasise or remove references to the United Kingdom.cite bookPhillip Alfred BucknerCanada and the end of empirehttp://books.google.com/books?id2005UBC Press978-0-7748-0916-086Other prominent symbols include theCanada goose,Great northern loonloonand more recently, thetotem poleandinuksuk.cite journalRuhlJeffreyJanuary 2008Inukshuk RisingCanadian Journal of Globalization1125–30Symbols of the monarchy in Canada continue to be featured in, for example, theArms of Canadaand armed forcesHer Majesty's Canadian Ship. The designation 'monarchyRoyal' remains for institutions as varied as theRoyal Canadian Mounted Policeand theRoyal Winnipeg Ballet. DuringUnification of the Canadian Forcesunification of the forcesin the 1960s, a renaming of the branches took place, resulting in the abandonment of "royal designations" of the navy and air force.cite bookDouglas J. MurrayPaul R. ViottiThe defense policies of nations: a comparative studyhttp://books.google.com/books?id1994JHU Press978-0-8018-4794-384On August 16, 2011, the Government of Canada announced that the name "Air Command" was re-assuming the air force's original historic name,Royal Canadian Air Force; "Land Command" was re-assuming the nameCanadian Army; and "Maritime Command" was re-assuming the nameRoyal Canadian Navy.cite webhttp://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2011.08.0889.htmlRestoration of traditional military service names welcomedGovernment of New Brunswick (Intergovernmental Affairs Office of the Premier)2011January 1, 2012These name changes were made to better reflectMilitary history of CanadaCanada's military heritageand align Canada with other keyCommonwealth of Nationswhose militaries use the royal designation.
article.heading: Humour
article.paragraph: MainCanadian humourCanadian humouris an integral part of the Canadian Identity. There are several traditions in Canadian humour in bothCanadian EnglishEnglishandQuebec FrenchFrench.Scobie, Stephen"Humorous Writing in English".The Canadian Encyclopedia.Retrieved on: April 23, 2010.Lacombe, Michelle"Humorous Writing in French".The Canadian Encyclopedia.Retrieved on: April 23, 2010.While these traditions are distinct and at times very different, there are common themes that relate to Canadians' shared history andgeopoliticsgeopoliticalsituation in the Western Hemisphere and the world. Various trends can be noted in Canadian comedy. One trend is the portrayal of a "typical" Canadian family in an ongoing radio or television series.cite bookDoug OwramBorn at the right time: a history of the baby-boom generationhttp://books.google.com/books?id1997University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-8086-891Other trends include outright absurdity,cite bookCharles BobergThe English Language in Canada: Status, History and Comparative Analysishttp://books.google.com/books?id2010Cambridge University Press978-0-521-87432-845and political and cultural satire.cite bookWilliam H. NewEncyclopedia of literature in Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2002University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-0761-2516Satire and self-deprecation are arguably the primary characteristics of Canadian humour.MacGregor, p.61cite bookSerra Ayse TinicOn location: Canada's television industry in a global markethttp://books.google.com/books?id2005University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-8548-1131cite bookStephen BrooksThe challenge of cultural pluralismhttp://books.google.com/books?id2002Greenwood Publishing Group978-0-275-97001-745

link.target: File:Festival Juste pour rire de Montral, Qubec.jpg
link.part: Just for Laughs Festivalin Montreal, Qubec at theThtre Saint-DenisSaint-Denis Theatre.

article.paragraph: The beginnings of Canadian radio comedy date to the late 1930s with the debut ofThe Happy Gang, a long-running weekly variety show that was regularly sprinkled with corny jokes in between tunes.cite bookGil MurrayNothing on but the radio: a look back at radio in Canada and how it changed the worldhttp://books.google.com/books?id2003Dundurn Press Ltd.978-1-55002-479-139Canadian television comedy begins withWayne and Shuster, a sketch comedy duo who performed as a comedy team during the Second World War, and moved their act to radio in 1946 before moving on to television.cite bookDoug Hill, Jeff WeingradSaturday Night: A Backstage History of Saturday Night Lifehttp://books.google.com/books?idUntreed Reads978-1-61187-218-7272011-12-15Second City Television, otherwise known asSecond City TelevisionSCTV,Royal Canadian Air Farce,This Hour Has 22 Minutes,The Kids in the Halland more recentlyTrailer Park Boysare regarded as television shows which were very influential on the development of Canadian humour.cite bookMaurice CharneyComedy: a geographic and historical guidehttp://books.google.com/books?id2005Greenwood Publishing Group978-0-313-32714-8210–213List of Canadian comediansCanadian comedianshave had great success in the film industry and are amongst the most recognized in the world.

Humber Collegein Toronto and the cole nationale de l'humour in Montreal offer post-secondary programmes in comedy writing and performance.cite webhttp://www.culturalhrc.ca/membership/members-e.aspOrganisation MembersCultural Human Resources Council2010February 2, 2012Montrealis also home to the bilingual (English and French)Just for Laughsfestival and to theJust for Laughs Museum, a bilingual, international museum of comedy.cite bookJohn Robert Colombo1000 questions about Canada: places, people, things, and ideas : a question-and-answer book on Canadian facts and culturehttp://books.google.com/books?id2001Dundurn Press Ltd.978-0-88882-232-1213Canada has a national television channel,The Comedy Network, devoted to comedy. Many Canadian cities feature comedy clubs and showcases, most notable,The Second Citybranch in Toronto (originally housed atThe Old Fire Hall) and theYuk Yuk'snational chain.cite bookRobert A. StebbinsThe laugh-makers: stand-up comedy as art, business, and life-stylehttp://books.google.com/books?id1990McGill-Queen's University Press978-0-7735-0735-725The Canadian Comedy Awardswere founded in 1999 by the Canadian Comedy Foundation for Excellence, a not-for-profit organization.cite webHistoryhttp://canadiancomedy.ca/history.php2012The Canadian Comedy Awards & FestivalFebruary 3, 2012
article.heading: Arts
Visual arts
article.paragraph: MainCanadian artFile:The Jack Pine, by Tom Thomson.jpgthumb180px''Jack Pine (painting)The Jack Pine'', byTom Thomson, 1916. Oil on canvas, in the collection of theNational Gallery of CanadaAboriginal artists were producing art in the territory that is now called Canada for thousands of years prior to the arrival of European settler colonists and the eventual establishment of Canada as a nation state.cite bookRuth B. PhillipsMuseum Pieces: Toward the Indigenization of Canadian Museumshttp://books.google.com/books?id2011McGill-Queen's University Press978-0-7735-3905-1267Like the peoples that produced them,Visual arts by indigenous peoples of the Americasindigenous art traditionsspanned territories that extended across the current national boundaries between Canada and the United States.cite bookJohn W. FriesenVirginia Agnes Lyons FriesenCanadian Aboriginal Art and Spirituality: A Vital Link2006Detselig EnterprisesCalgary, ABxxi – Intro978155059304462129850The majority of indigenous artworks preserved in museum collections date from the period after European contact and show evidence of the creative adoption and adaptation of European trade goods such as metal and glass beads.cite bookJ. Russell HarperPainting in Canada: a historyhttp://books.google.com/books?id1977University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-6307-657Canadian sculpture has been enriched by the walrus ivory, muskox horn and caribou antler and soapstone carvings by theInuit artists.cite bookNicola FörgCanada: Pacific coast, the Rockies, Prairie Provinces, and the Territorieshttp://books.google.com/books?id1999Hunter Publishing, Inc978-3-88618-368-5233These carvings show objects and activities from the daily life, myths and legends of the Inuit.cite bookPatricia Randolph LeighInternational Exploration of Technology Equity and the Digital Divide: Critical, Historical and Social Perspectiveshttp://books.google.com/books?id2010Idea Group Inc (IGI)978-1-61520-793-093Inuit art since the 1950s has been the traditional gift given to foreign dignitaries by the Canadian government.cite bookPamela R. SternDaily life of the Inuithttp://books.google.com/books?id2010ABC-CLIO978-0-313-36311-5151

The works of most early Canadian painters followed European trends.cite bookRoshen DalalThe Illustrated Timeline of the History of the Worldhttp://books.google.com/books?id2011The Rosen Publishing Group978-1-4488-4797-6147During the mid-19th century,Cornelius Krieghoff, a Dutch-born artist in Quebec, painted scenes of the life of thehabitants(French-Canadian farmers). At about the same time, the Canadian artistPaul Kanepainted pictures of aboriginal life in western Canada. A group of landscape painters called theGroup of Seven (artists)Group of Sevendeveloped the first distinctly Canadian style of painting.cite bookLynda JessupAntimodernism and artistic experience: policing the boundaries of modernityhttp://books.google.com/books?id2001University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-8354-8146All these artists painted large, brilliantly coloured scenes of the Canadian wilderness.

Since the 1930s, Canadian painters have developed a wide range of highly individual styles.Emily Carrbecame famous for her paintings oftotem polesin British Columbia.cite bookCheryl MacDonaldCelebrated Pets: Endearing Tales of Companionship and Loyaltyhttp://books.google.com/books?id2009Heritage House Publishing Co978-1-894974-81-357–Other noted painters have included the landscape artistDavid Milne (artist)David Milne, thepaintersJean-Paul Riopelle,Harold TownandCharles Carson (painter)Charles Carsonand multi-media artistMichael Snow. The abstract art groupPainters Eleven, particularly the artistsWilliam RonaldandJack Bush, also had an important impact on modern art in Canada.cite bookIris NowellPainters Eleven: The Wild Ones of Canadian Arthttp://books.google.com/books?id2011Douglas & McIntyre978-1-55365-590-933Government support has played a vital role in their development enabling visual exposure through publications and periodicals featuring Canadian art, as has the establishment of numerous art schools and colleges across the country.cite bookSarah M. CorseNationalism and literature: the politics of culture in Canada and the United Stateshttp://books.google.com/books?id1997Cambridge University Press978-0-521-57912-460
article.heading: Literature
article.paragraph: Canadian literatureis often divided into French- and English-language literatures, which are rooted in the literary traditions of France and Britain, respectively.cite bookW. J. KeithCanadian literature in Englishhttp://books.google.com/books?id2006The Porcupine's Quill978-0-88984-283-019Canadas early literature, whether written in English or French, often reflects the Canadian perspective on nature, frontier life, and Canadas position in the world, for example the poetry ofBliss Carmanor the memoirs ofSusanna MoodieandCatherine Parr Traill. These themes, and Canada's literary history, inform the writing of successive generations of Canadian authors, fromLeonard CohentoMargaret Atwood.

By the mid-20th century, Canadian writers were exploring national themes for Canadian readers. Authors were trying to find a distinctly Canadian voice, rather than merely emulating British or American writers. Canadian identity is closely tied to its literature. The question of national identity recurs as a theme in much of Canada's literature, fromHugh MacLennan'sTwo Solitudes (novel)Two Solitudes(1945) toAlistair MacLeod'sNo Great Mischief(1999). Canadian literature is often categorized byList of regions of Canadaregion or province; by the socio-cultural origins of the author (for example,Acadians, Aboriginal peoples, LGBT, andIrish Canadians); and by literary period, such as "Canadian postmoderns" or "Canadian Poets Between the Wars."

Canadian authors have accumulated numerous international awards.cite webhttp://www.robertfulford.com/CanadianNovelists.htmlRobert Fulford's column about the international success of Canadian literatureRobertfulford.comJune 6, 2001February 25, 2011In 1992,Michael Ondaatjebecame the first Canadian to win theMan Booker PrizeforThe English Patient.cite bookMary Virginia BrackettVictoria GaydosikThe Facts on File Companion to the British Novel: Beginnings through the 19th centuryhttp://books.google.com/books?id2006Infobase Publishing978-0-8160-5133-5323Margaret Atwoodwon the Booker in 2000 forThe Blind Assassincite bookShannon Eileen HengenAshley ThomsonMargaret Atwood: a reference guide, 1988–2005http://books.google.com/books?id2007Scarecrow Press978-0-8108-5904-3272andYann Martelwon it in 2002 for theLife of Pi.cite bookYann MartelBeatrice and Virgilhttp://books.google.com/books?id2010Random House Digital, Inc.978-0-8129-8197-1212Carol Shields'sThe Stone Diarieswon theGovernor General's Awardsin Canada in 1993, the 1995Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, and the 1994National Book Critics Circle Award.cite bookAbby H. P. WerlockCarol Shields's The stone diaries: a reader's guidehttp://books.google.com/books?id2001Continuum International Publishing Group978-0-8264-5249-869In 2013,Alice Munrowas the first Canadian to be awarded theNobel Prize in LiteratureforList of short stories by Alice Munroher workas "master of the modern short story".cite press releasehttp://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/2013/press.pdfThe Nobel Prize in Literature 2013PDF2013October 10, 2013Munro is also a recipient of the Man Booker International Prize for her lifetime body of work, and three-time winner of Canada's Governor General's Award for fiction.cite bookJulia GaunceSuzette MayrDon LePanMarjorie MatherBryanne MillerThe Broadview Anthology of Short Fiction, second editionhttp://books.google.com/books?idJuly 25, 2012Broadview Press978-1-55481-076-5236
article.heading: Theatre
article.paragraph: MainTheatre of CanadaCanada has had a thriving stage theatre scene since the late 1800s.cite bookBeth OsnesActing: an International encyclopediahttp://books.google.com/books?id2001ABC-CLIO978-0-87436-795-957Theatre festivals draw many tourists in the summer months, especially theStratford Shakespeare FestivalinStratford, OntarioStratford, Ontario, and theShaw FestivalinNiagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario. TheFamous People Playersare only one of many touring companies that have also developed an international reputation.cite bookGuek Cheng PangCanadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2004Marshall Cavendish978-0-7614-1788-0102–Canada also hosts one of the largestFringe theatrefringe festivaltheEdmonton International Fringe Festival.cite bookGuek Cheng PangCanadahttp://books.google.com/books?id2004Marshall Cavendish978-0-7614-1788-0121–File:Grand Opera House and Majestic Theatre, Adelaide Street, Toronto, Canada.JPGthumbA 1904 postcard showing theGrand Opera House (Toronto)Grand Opera Houseand Majestic Theatre, Adelaide Street, in the currentToronto Theatre District.

List of census metropolitan areas and agglomerations in CanadaCanada's largest citieshost a variety of modern and historical venues. TheToronto Theatre Districtis Canada's largest, as well as being the third largest English-speaking theatre district in the world.cite bookAngeliniPaul UbaldoOur Society: Human Diversity in Canada2011Cengage Learning978017650354334In addition to original Canadian works, shows from the West End and Broadway frequently tour in Toronto. Toronto's Theatre District includes the venerableRoy Thomson Hall; thePrincess of Wales Theatre; theTim Sims Playhouse;The Second City; theCanon Theatre; thePanasonic Theatre; theRoyal Alexandra Theatre; historicMassey Hall; and the city's new opera house, theSony Centre for the Performing Arts.cite webhttp://www.showmetoronto.com/toronto_tour_theatre_district.htmToronto Theatre DistrictShowmetoronto.com2013-02-12Toronto's Theatre District also includes theTheatre Museum Canada.

Montreal's theatre district ("Quartier des Spectacles") is the scene of performances that are mainly French-language, although the city also boasts a lively anglophone theatre scene, such as theCentaur Theatre.cite webhttp://www.quartierdesspectacles.com/en/discover/DiscoverQuartier des spectacles2013-02-12Large French theatres in the city includeTheatre Saint-Denis,Theatre du Nouveau Monde, andEXcentris.cite webhttp://www.hahaha.com/en/montreal/performances/byplace/5138Montreal Festival | Just For LaughsHahaha.com2013-02-12

Vancouveris host to, among others, theVancouver Fringe Festival, theArts Club Theatre Company,Carousel Theatre,Bard on the Beach,Theatre Under the Stars (Vancouver)Theatre Under the StarsandStudio 58.cite webTheatre BChttp://theatrebc.org/theatre-links/Theatre LinksTheatre BC2013-02-13It also home ofVancouver Theatresports League, theimprovisational theatrecompany, wold-known for providing an impetus for the present worldwide interest intheatresportsatExpo 86Expoin 1986.

Calgaryis home toTheatre Calgary, a mainstream regional theatre;Alberta Theatre Projects, a major centre for new play development in Canada; theCalgary Animated Objects Society; andOne Yellow Rabbit, a touring company.cite webhttp://www.calgaryartsdevelopment.com/files/OperatingGrantRecipients2011_0.pdf2011Calgary Arts Development (CADA)2011 Operating Grant Recipients2013-02-13

There are three major theatre venues inOttawa; theOttawa Little Theatre, originally called the Ottawa Drama League at its inception in 1913, is the longest-running community theatre company in Ottawa.cite bookJamesHaleFrommer's Ottawahttp://books.google.com/books?id2011John Wiley and Sons60978-0-470-68158-9Since 1969, Ottawa has been the home of theNational Arts Centre, a major performing-arts venue that houses four stages and is home to theNational Arts Centre Orchestra, theOttawa Symphony OrchestraandOpera Lyra Ottawa.cite webhttp://www.nac-cna.ca/en/about/nachistory/index.cfmNAC History | National Arts CentreNac-cna.ca1970-03-172011-06-07Established in 1975, theGreat Canadian Theatre Companyspecializes in the production of Canadian plays at a local level.cite webhttp://www.canadiantheatre.com/dict.pl?termGreat Canadian Theatre CompanyCanadian Theatre Encyclopedia2011-01-132011-09-01
article.heading: Television
article.paragraph: mainTelevision in CanadaFile:CBC Centre.JPGthumbCBC's English-language master control point, theCanadian Broadcasting Centre, in TorontoCanadian television, especially supported by theCanadian Broadcasting Corporation,cite bookJulie K. PetersenThe telecommunications illustrated dictionaryhttp://books.google.com/books?id2002CRC Press978-0-8493-1173-4152is the home of a variety of locally produced shows. French-language television, like French Canadian film, is buffered from excessive American influence by the fact of language, and likewise supports a host of home-grown productions.cite bookPatrick JamesMark J. KasoffCanadian Studies in the New Millenniumhttp://books.google.com/books?id2008University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-9468-1157The success of French-language domestic television in Canada often exceeds that of its English-language counterpart. In recent years nationalism has been used to prompt products on television. TheI Am Canadiancampaign byMolsonbeer, most notably the commercial featuring Joe Canadian, infusedBeer in Canadadomestically brewed beerand nationalism.cite bookJosé Eduardo IgartuaThe other quiet revolution: national identities in English Canada, 1945–71http://books.google.com/books?id2006UBC Press978-0-7748-1088-3229

Canada's television industry is in full expansion as a site for Hollywood productions.cite bookVincent MoscoDan SchillerContinental order?: integrating North America for cybercapitalismhttp://books.google.com/books?id2001Rowman & Littlefield978-0-7425-0954-2208Since the 1980s, Canada, and Vancouver in particular, has become known asHollywood North.cite bookJohn PunterThe Vancouver achievement: urban planning and designhttp://books.google.com/books?id2003UBC Press978-0-7748-0971-94The American TV seriesQueer as Folk (North American TV series)Queer as Folkwas filmed in Toronto. Canadian producers have been very successful in the field ofCanadian science fiction televisionscience fictionsince the mid-1990s, with such shows asThe X-Files,Stargate SG-1, theBattlestar Galactica (2004 TV series)new ''Battlestar Galactica'',My Babysitter's a Vampire (TV series)My Babysitter's A Vampire,Smallville, andThe Outer Limits (1995 TV series)The Outer Limits, all filmed in Vancouver.cite bookMike ResnickNebula Awards Showcase 2007http://books.google.com/books?id2007Penguin978-1-4406-2261-8111

The CRTC's Canadian content regulations dictate that a certain percentage of a domestic broadcaster's transmission time must include content that is produced by Canadians, or covers Canadian subjects.cite bookJay G. BlumlerT. J. NossiterBroadcasting Finance in Transition: A Comparative Handbookhttp://books.google.com/books?id1991Oxford University Press978-0-19-505089-932These regulations also apply toCable television in the United StatesUS cable televisionchannels such asMTV CanadaMTVand theDiscovery Channel (Canada)Discovery Channel, which have local versions of their channels available onMultichannel television in CanadaCanadian cable networks. Similarly,BBC Canada, while showing primarilyBBCshows from the United Kingdom, also carries Canadian output.
article.heading: Film
article.paragraph: A number ofCanadian pioneers in early Hollywoodsignificantly contributed to the creation of the motion picture industry in the early days of the 20th century.cite bookDana RasmussenCanada's Influence on the Film Industry: Canada's Pioneers in Early Hollywood2011BiblioBazaariix (intro)Over the years, many Canadians have made enormous contributions to the American entertainment industry, although they are frequently not recognized as Canadians.cite bookCharles FosterStardust and shadows: Canadians in early Hollywoodhttp://books.google.com/books?id2000Dundurn Press Ltd.978-1-55002-348-027–34

link.part: Standard Theatre (Toronto)Standard Theatre, 482 Queen Street West, Toronto, Canada, 1906

article.paragraph: Canada has developed a vigorous film industry that has produced a variety of well-known films, actors, and auteurs.cite bookGorham Anders KindemThe international movie industryhttp://books.google.com/books?id2000SIU Press (reprint)978-0-8093-2299-2304–307In fact, this eclipsing may sometimes be creditable for the bizarre and innovative directions of some works,such as auteursAtom Egoyan(The Sweet Hereafter (film)The Sweet Hereafter, 1997) andDavid Cronenberg(The Fly (1986 film)The Fly,Naked Lunch (film)Naked Lunch,A History of Violence (film)A History of Violence). Also, the distinct French-Canadian society permits the work of directors such asDenys ArcandandDenis Villeneuve. At the76th Academy Awards, Arcand'sThe Barbarian Invasionsbecame Canada's first film to win theAcademy Award for Best Foreign Language Film.cite bookGraham FraserSorry, I Don't Speak French: Confronting the Canadian Crisis That Won't Go Awayhttp://books.google.com/books?id2007Random House Digital, Inc.978-0-7710-4767-1227James Cameronis a very successful Canadian filmmaker, having been nominated for and receiving manyAcademy Awards.cite bookMark KearneyRandy RayThe Great Canadian Trivia Book 2http://books.google.com/books?id1998Dundurn Press Ltd.978-0-88882-197-380–

TheNational Film Board of Canadais 'a public agency that produces and distributes films and other audiovisual works which reflect Canada to Canadians and the rest of the world'.cite bookEwan FerlieLaurence E. LynnChristopher PollittThe Oxford handbook of public managementhttp://books.google.com/books?id2007Oxford Handbooks Online978-0-19-922644-3457Canada has produced many popular documentaries such asThe Corporation (film)The Corporation,Nanook of the North,Final Offer, andCanada: A People's History. The Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) is considered by many to be one of the most prevalent film festivals for Western cinema. It is the premire film festival in North America from which the Oscars race begins.cite webhttp://www.tiff.net/default.aspxToronto International Film FestivalTiff.netFebruary 25, 2011
article.heading: Music
article.paragraph: File:Ojazzfest.JPG200pxthumbOttawa Jazz FestivalinsideRideau Centre, 2008Themusic of Canadahas reflected the multi-cultural influences that have shaped the country.Aboriginal peoples in CanadaAboriginals, the French, and the British have all made contributions to the musical heritage of Canada. The country has produced its ownList of Canadian composerscomposers,List of Canadian musiciansmusiciansandMusical ensembleensemblessince the mid-1600s.Music in Canada 16001800. by Amtmann, Willy. Cambridge, Ont. : Habitex Books, 1975. 320 p.(ISBN 0-88912-020-X)La Musique au Qubec 16001875. by Michelle Pharand. Montreal: Les ditions de l'Homme (1976) (ISBN 0-7759-0517-8)From the 17th century onward, Canada has developed a music infrastructure that includeschurch halls;Chamber musicchamber halls;College or university school of musicconservatories;Academyacademies;performing arts centres;Record labelrecord companys;Radio broadcastingradio stations, and television music-video channels.cite bookCarl MoreyMusic in Canada: a research and information guidehttp://books.google.com/books?id1997Garland Pub.978-0-8153-1603-9??cite webhttp://www.broadcasting-history.ca/timeline/CCFTimeline.htmlThe history of broadcasting in CanadaThe Canadian Communications FoundationThe music has subsequently been heavily influenced by American culture because of its proximity and migration between the two countries.Profiles of Canada. edited by Kenneth G. Pryke, Walter C. Soderlund. Boulder, Colo. : NetLibrary, 2000.(ISBN 0-585-27925-X)cite webhttp://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNmHistory of Canada in musicHistorica Foundation of CanadaCanadian Music: Issues of Hegemony & Identity, eds Beveley Diamond & Robert Witmer. Canadian Scholars Press, 1994.Canadian rockhas had a considerable impact on the development of modernpopular musicand the development of the most popularCanadian music genressubgenres.cite bookJoan NicksJeannette SloniowskiSlippery pastimes: reading the popular in Canadian culturehttp://books.google.com/books?id2002Wilfrid Laurier Univ. Press978-0-88920-388-4219

Anthems and nationalistic songs of CanadaPatriotic music in Canadadate back over 200 years as a distinct category from British patriotism, preceding theConstitution Act, 1867first legal steps to independenceby over 50 years. The earliest, "The Bold Canadian", was written in 1812.cite bookAdam JortnerThe Gods of Prophetstown: The Battle of Tippecanoe and the Holy War for the American Frontierhttp://books.google.com/books?id2011Oxford University Press978-0-19-976529-4217The national anthem of Canada,O Canadaadopted in 1980,cite webGovernment of Canada Hymne national du Canada Canadian Heritage Government of Canada 2008-06-23 http://www.pch.gc.ca/pgm/ceem-cced/symbl/anthem-fra.cfm 2008-06-26was originally commissioned by theLieutenant Governor of Quebec, the HonourableThodore Robitaille, for the 1880Fte nationale du QubecSt. Jean-Baptiste Dayceremony.cite webhttp://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm'O Canada'Historica-DominionOctober 28, 2009Calixa Lavallewrote the music, which was a setting of a patriotic poem composed by the poet and judge SirAdolphe-Basile Routhier. The text was originally only in French, before it was translated to English in 1906.cite webHymne national du Canada Canadian Heritage June 23, 2008 http://www.pch.gc.ca/pgm/ceem-cced/symbl/anthem-fra.cfm June 26, 2008

Music broadcasting in the country is regulated by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC). TheCanadian Academy of Recording Arts and Sciencespresents Canada's music industry awards, theJuno Awards, which were first awarded in a ceremony during the summer of 1970.cite bookhttp://books.google.com/books?id127Canadian content, culture and the quest for nationhoodRyanEdwardsonUniversity of Toronto Press2008978-0-8020-9759-0
article.heading: Video games
article.paragraph: mainVideo gaming in CanadaCanada has one of the largest video-game industries in terms of employment numbers, right behind the USA and Japan,cite webhttp://www.networkworld.com/news/2010/040610-canada-boasts-the-third-largest-video.htmlCanada boasts the third-largest video game industryNetworkworld.comApril 6, 2010May 12, 2011with 16,000 employees, 348 companies, and a direct annual economic impact of nearly $2 billion.cite webCanada's Video Game Industry in 2011http://www.techvibes.com/blog/canadas-video-game-industry-in-2011-infographic-2011-10-30Tech VibesNovember 10, 2011Canada has grown from a minor player in the video-games industry to a major industry player.cite newsThe evolution of video games in Canada[[CBC News]]September 13, 2010http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/story/2010/09/09/f-videogames-history.htmlMay 11, 2011cite newsCanadian-made games and the question of outsourcing[[CBC News]]February 20, 2011http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/story/2011/02/04/f-video-game-developers-subsidies.htmlMay 23, 2011In part, this prominence is made possible by a large pool of university-educated talent and a high quality of life, but favourable government policies towardsdigital mediacompanies also play a role in making Canada an attractive location for game development studios.cite webhttp://business.financialpost.com/2011/05/30/canadas-home-grown-video-game-industry-shines-on-international-stage/Canada’s gaming industry is kicking butt | FP Tech Desk | Financial PostBusiness.financialpost.comFebruary 3, 2012
article.heading: Media
article.paragraph: mainMedia in CanadaFile:APTN building on Portage Avenue in Winnipeg, Manitoba.JPGthumbAboriginal Peoples Television Networkheadquarters inWinnipeg, Manitoba.Canada has a well-developedMass mediamediasector, but its cultural outputparticularly inEnglish languageEnglishfilms, television shows, and magazinesis often overshadowed by imports from the United States.cite bookMike BrakeComparative Youth Culture: The Sociology of Youth Cultures and Youth Subcultures in America, Britain, and Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id1990Routledge978-0-415-05108-8160Television, magazines, and newspapers are primarily for-profit corporations based onadvertising,subscription, and other sales-related revenues. Nevertheless, both the television broadcasting and publications sectors require a number of government interventions to remain profitable, ranging from regulation that bars foreign companies in the broadcasting industry to tax laws that limit foreign competition in magazine advertising.cite bookSteven GlobermanInstitute for Research on Public PolicyCultural Regulation in Canadahttp://books.google.com/books?id1983IRPP978-0-920380-81-918

The promotion ofmulticultural media in Canadabegan in the late 1980s as the multicultural policy was legislated in 1988.cite bookRobin MansellMarc RaboyThe Handbook of Global Media and Communication Policyhttp://books.google.com/books?id2011John Wiley & Sons978-1-4443-9542-6In theCanadian Multiculturalism ActMulticulturalism Act, the federal government proclaimed the recognition of the diversity of Canadian culture.Thus, multicultural media became an integral part of Canadian media overall. Upon numerous government reports showing lack of minority representation or minority misrepresentation, the Canadian government stressed separate provision be made to allow minorities and ethnicities of Canada to have their own voice in the media.cite bookPaul AttallahLeslie Regan ShadeMediascapes: new patterns in Canadian communication2006Thomson Nelson978-0-17-640652-3227
article.heading: Sport
article.paragraph: See alsoSports in CanadaSports in Canadaconsists of a variety of games. Although there are many contests that Canadians value, the most common areIce hockey,Lacrosse,Canadian football, basketball, soccer,curling, baseball andringette. All but curling and soccer are considered domestic sports as they were either invented by Canadians or trace their roots to Canada.cite bookDon MorrowKevin B. WamsleySport in Canada: A History2013Oxford University Press978-0-19-544672-21–4

link.part: A scene at the2010 Winter OlympicsinVancouverseconds afterCanada men's national ice hockey teamTeam Canadawon gold in men'sice hockey.

article.paragraph: Ice hockey, referred to as simply "hockey", is Canada's most prevalentNational sportwinter sport, its most popular spectator sport, and its most successful sport in international competition. It is Canada's official national winter sport.cite bookBruce KiddThe struggle for Canadian sporthttp://books.google.com/books?id1996University of Toronto Press978-0-8020-7664-9189–Lacrosse, a sport withIndigenous peoples of the Americasindigenousorigins, is Canada's oldest andNational sportofficial summer sport.Canadian footballis Canada's second most popular spectator sport,cite newsCanadian Press Canadian Press June 8, 2006 http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20060608.wsurvey8/BNStory/Sports/home Survey: Canadian interest in pro football is on the rise Globe and MailCanada June 8, 2006and theCanadian Football League's annual championship, theGrey Cup, is the country's largest annual sports event.cite bookGlenn M. WongThe comprehensive guide to careers in sportshttp://books.google.com/books?id2009Jones & Bartlett Learning978-0-7637-2884-7105

While other sports have a larger spectator base, association football, known in Canada assoccerin both English and French, has the most registered players of any team sport in Canada, and is the most played sport with all demographics, including ethnic origin, ages and genders.cite newsCanada.com Canada's hockey obsession leading to burnout among young players September 16, 2008 http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/sports/story.html?idProfessional teams exist in many cities in Canada and international soccer competitions such as theFIFA World Cup,UEFA European ChampionshipUEFA Euroand theUEFA Champions Leagueattract some of the biggest audiences in Canada.cite newshttp://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/story/2010/07/12/sp-ratings.htmlWorld Cup TV ratings and soccer championships show huge riseCBC NewsOther popular team sports includecurling,street hockey,cricket,rugby union in CanadarugbysoftballandUltimate (sport)Ultimate frisbee. Popular individual sports includeauto racing,boxing,karate,kickboxing, hunting, fishing, cycling, golf, hiking,horse racing,ice skating,skiing,snowboarding, swimming,triathlon,disc golf,water sport (recreation)water sports, and several forms ofwrestling.

As a country with a generally cool climate, Canada has enjoyed greater success at theCanada at the Winter OlympicsWinter Olympicsthan at theCanada at the Summer OlympicsSummer Olympics, although significant regional variations in climate allow for a wide variety of both team and individual sports. Great achievements in Canadian sports are recognized byCanada's Sports Hall of Fame,cite bookVictor J. DanilovHall of fame museums: a reference guidehttp://books.google.com/books?id1997Greenwood Publishing Group978-0-313-30000-424while theLou Marsh Trophyis awarded annually to Canada's top athlete by a panel of journalists.cite bookEdward ZawadzkiThe Ultimate Canadian Sports Trivia Bookhttp://books.google.com/books?id2001Dundurn Press Ltd.978-0-88882-237-6190There are numerous other Sports Halls of Fame in Canada.
article.heading: Cuisine
article.paragraph: File:CanadianCuisineSubset.pngthumb160pxA small sampling of Canadian foods. ''Clockwise from top left'':Montreal-style smoked meat,maple syrup,poutine,Nanaimo bar,butter tart,peameal baconmainCanadian cuisineCanadian cuisinevaries widely depending on theList of regions of Canadaregion. The former Canadian prime ministerJoe Clarkhas been paraphrased to have noted: "Canada has a cuisine of cuisines. Not a stew pot, but a smorgasbord."citationGeorgePandiLet's eat Canadian, but is there really a national dish?The Gazette (Montreal)April 5, 2008http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/columnists/story.html?idAlso published as "Canadian cuisine a smorgasbord of regional flavours"There are considerable overlaps between Canadian food and the rest of the cuisine in North America, many unique dishes (or versions of certain dishes) are found and available only in the country. Common contenders for the CanadianNational dishnational foodincludepoutinecitationCalvinTrillinCanadian Journal, 'Funny Food'The New YorkerNovember 23, 200968–70citationCanada's national dish: 740 calories—and worth every bite?October 2, 2010GraceWongCNNhttp://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/americas/10/02/canada.poutine/index.htmlcitationIs poutine Canada’s national food? Two arguments for, two againstJonSufrinApril 22, 2010Toronto Lifehttp://www.torontolife.com/daily/daily-dish/aprons-icons/2010/04/22/is-poutine-canadas-national-food-two-arguments-for-two-against/andbutter tarts.citationDoes Canada Have a National Dish?http://www.canadianliving.com/blogs/food/2009/06/30/does-canada-have-a-national-dish/ElizabethBairdJune 30, 2009Canadian LivingcitationCanadians butter up to this tartRITADeMONTISToronto SunJune 21, 2010http://www.torontosun.com/life/eat/2010/03/04/13112421.htmlA noteworthy fact is that Canada is the world's largest producer ofmaple syrup."Maple Syrup."Ontario Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs. Accessed July 2011.

The three earliest cuisines of Canada haveFirst Nations, English, and French roots, with the traditional cuisine ofEnglish Canadaclosely related toBritish cuisineBritishandCuisine of the United StatesAmerican cuisine, while the traditional cuisine ofFrench Canadahas evolved fromFrench cuisineand the winter provisions ofCoureur des boisfur traders.cite bookLinda CivitelloCuisine and Culture: A History of Food and Peoplehttp://books.google.com/books?id2011John Wiley & Sons978-0-470-40371-6401–402With subsequent waves of immigration in the 18th and 19th century fromCentral EuropeCentral,Southern EuropeSouthern, and Eastern Europe, and then from Asia, Africa andCaribbean, the regional cuisines were subsequently augmented.TheJewish CanadianJewish immigrantsto Canada during the late 1800s also play a significant role to foods in Canada. TheMontreal-style bagelandMontreal-style smoked meatare both food items originally developed by Jewish communities living inMontreal.cite bookGail SimmonsTalking with My Mouth Full: My Life as a Professional Eaterhttp://books.google.com/books?id2012Hyperion978-1-4013-0415-745
article.heading: Outside views
article.paragraph: In 1984,John Wilson, 2nd Baron MoranBaron Moran, the British High Commissioner to Canada, stated that, in his opinion, Canadians have limited talents and are "deeply unimpressive." Said Moran, "Anyone who is even moderately good at what they doin literature, the theater, skiing or whatevertends to become a national figure. And anyone who stands out at all from the crowd tends to be praised to the skies and given theOrder of Canadaat once."(Associated Press), "Letters reveal candid views of UK diplomats",WTOP-FMWTOP, October 18, 2009.

In a 2002 interview with the Globe and Mail,Aga Khan IVAga Khan, the 49th Imam of theIsmailiIsmaili Muslims, described Canada as "the most successfulPluralism (political philosophy)pluralist societyon the face of our globe",cite bookLinda A. WhiteRichard SimeonThe Comparative Turn in Canadian Political Sciencehttp://books.google.com/books?id2009UBC Press978-0-7748-1428-7102citing it as "a model for the world".citationCanada: 'A model for the world' February 2, 2002 Stackhouse, John Martin, Patrick F3 [[The Globe and Mail]] Toronto http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/columnists/doug-saunders/canadas-mistaken-identity/article1199074/ June 29, 2009 Canada is today the most successful pluralist society on the face of our globe, without any doubt in my mind. . . . That is something unique to Canada. It is an amazing global human asset A 2007 poll ranked Canada as the country with the most positive influence in the world. 28,000 people in 27 countries were asked to rate 12 countries as either having a positive or negative worldwide influence. Canadas overall influence rating topped the list with 54 per cent of respondents rating it mostly positive and only 14 per cent mostly negative.cite webhttp://www.canadavisa.com/canada-a-good-influence-on-the-world.htmlCanada – A Good Influence on the WorldCanadavisa.comMarch 7, 2007June 30, 2010

The United States is home to a number of perceptions about Canadian culture, due to the countries' partially shared heritage and the relatively large number of cultural features common to both the US and Canada.cite webhttp://www.people-press.org/2004/01/14/americans-and-canadians/Americans and Canadians -The North American Not-so-odd Couple2004Pew Research CenterFor example, the average Canadian may be perceived as more reserved than his or her American counterpart.cite bookMercer Human Res Consulting, Inc.The Global Manager's Guide to Living and Working Abroad: Western Europe and the Americas: Western Europe and the Americashttp://books.google.com/books?id2009ABC-CLIO978-0-313-35884-567Canada and the United States are often inevitably compared as sibling countries, and the perceptions that arise from this oft-held contrast have gone to shape the advertised worldwide identities of both nations: the United States is seen as the rebellious child of the British Crown, forged in the fires ofAmerican Revolutionary Warviolent revolution; Canada is the calmer offspring of the United Kingdom, known for a more relaxed national demeanour.cite webhttp://seacoastnh.com/arts/please031404.htmlThe Myths that Made CanadaSeacoastNH.comAs I Please (column)48March 14, 2004June 10, 2011cite bookMel AtkeyBroadway North: The Dream of a Canadian Musical Theatrehttp://books.google.com/books?id2006Dundurn978-1-4597-2120-317
